item.title: 0. Rules and Expectations
item.description:
We come together to have fun and share a great adventure.
Treat everyone with respect and kindness.
Be considerate of each other's feelings and perspectives.
Communicate openly with the DM and fellow players.
If you have any concerns or ideas, please share them—constructive feedback helps improve the game for everyone.


We aim to create a safe and inclusive environment for all participants.
If any content or situation makes you uncomfortable, let the group or the DM know immediately.
We'll make adjustments to ensure everyone feels comfortable and included.


Our sessions are scheduled at specific times.
Please be punctual and ready to play at the agreed-upon time.
If you can't make it to a session, inform the group in advance.


Pay attention and stay engaged in the game.
Avoid distractions like mobile phones or side conversations during the session.
Immerse yourself in the story and contribute actively to the adventure.


Remember to separate your knowledge as a player from your character's knowledge.
Let your character discover information organically within the game world.
This maintains the integrity and excitement of the story.


Familiarize yourself with the basic rules of Dungeons & Dragons.
D&D is a collaborative storytelling experience; the goal is collective enjoyment rather than winning.
Play fair and respect the DM's rulings.
Don't hesitate to ask questions if you're unsure about something—it's okay to learn as you go.


Bring creativity to your character and actions.
Think outside the box and contribute to the narrative.
Your imagination is a key part of what makes the game exciting and memorable.


If conflicts arise, whether in-character or out-of-character, address them calmly and respectfully.
In-character conflicts can add depth to the story but should not affect real-life relationships among players.
The DM is there to help mediate and resolve issues.
Keep the focus on having a positive and enjoyable experience for everyone.


Character Development: Invest time in developing your character's backstory and motivations. This enriches the game for everyone.
Session Readiness: Ensure you have all necessary materials ready before the session starts, including updated character sheets and any personal notes.


Respect the game world and the narrative crafted by the DM.
Make decisions that align with your character's personality and background.
Help build a cohesive and immersive story by engaging with the setting and other characters.
DM Question
Does anyone have questions or need clarification on any of the ground rules?
Are there any additional ground rules you think we should include?
Is everyone comfortable with the expectations we've set for the game?


DM QuestionHow long can the group reasonably commit to playing?
Options: Specific number of weeks, months, or years.

DM QuestionHow often would the group like to play?
Options: Once a week, twice a month, monthly, etc.

DM QuestionWhich days and times work best for everyone?
Please discuss your availability and time zone considerations.

DM QuestionWhere shall we play our sessions? Decide on a primary location (physical venue or online platform) and a backup option.

DM QuestionWhere shall we play our sessions?
Decide on a primary location and a backup option.

DM QuestionHow long should we wait if someone is late before starting the session?
Options: Number of minutes to wait, or start on time regardless.

DM QuestionHow should we communicate if we're going to be late or absent?
Agree on a preferred method (e.g., group chat, text message) and any advance notice required.

DM Discussion PointUnder what circumstances should a session be canceled or rescheduled?
Discuss criteria such as the number of absent players, emergencies, or scheduling conflicts.

DM QuestionIf a player is absent, what should happen to their character? Options:
Be played by the DM.
Be played by another player.
Remain with the party but stay inactive.
Be absent from the party for that session.
Be controlled collectively by the group.





Dice, laptop/other way to access the VTT


DM QuestionHow should we determine character ability scores? Options:
Standard Array
Point Buy System
Rolling Dice
Player's Choice

DM RuleYou may select any playable species from:
The 2024 Player's Handbook AND
Any official Eberron sourcebooks, including::
Eberron: Rising From the Last War (2019, WotC)
Exploring Eberron (2020, Dungeon Masters Guild)
Chronicles of Eberron (2022, Dungeon Masters Guild)
Frontiers of Eberron: Quickstone (2024, Dungeon Masters Guild)
DM RuleAll classes from the 2024 Player's Handbook are available for this campaign. Classes found in other source material including Eberron sourcebooks are not available to play.

DM RuleFor this campaign, you have two options:
Pick a background from the PHB (Player's Handbook).
Create a custom background using the format below.

DM RuleDO NOT select any starting equipment. You will have gold from both your class and your background. Record this on your player sheet for now. You MAY select a starting trinket.

DM RuleYour characters are NOT dragonmarked

DM RuleCharacters with an evil alignment are not allowed in this campaign. Your character must be able to cooperate with the group and have motivations that fit the overall tone of the story. Consider creating a character who can work with others, even if they have different perspectives or goals.


DM DesireUse Exerience Points (XP)

DM QuestionHow should hit points be increased upon leveling up? Options:
Roll
Fixed by Class

DM QuestionHow should dice rolling be done? Options:
Real dice
Digital
Choice

DM QuestionHow should initiative rolling be done? Options:
Players roll individually
DM Roll all in VTT

DM QuestionHow strictly should we track encumbrance and inventory? Options:
Use standard encumbrance rules
Use simplified rules
Not track encumbrance
DM Magaic

Death is a significant aspect of the game that can greatly impact the story and player experience. It's important to find a balance between understanding the risks and consequences of death and ensuring that players don't take excessive risks due to a lack of meaningful repercussions.
Some considerations include:

Let-the-Dice-Fall-Where-They-May: Embrace the risk of combat where, if an enemy lands a critical hit, characters might die—even in the first session. This approach underscores the seriousness of dangerous situations and encourages careful decision-making.
Unconsciousness at Zero Hit Points: Dropping to zero hit points renders a character unconscious but not immediately dead, allowing for recovery as long as someone survives. This reduces sudden character deaths while still highlighting the peril of combat.
Flexible Resurrection Rules: Make resurrection more accessible by adjusting requirements (e.g., the cleric doesn't need diamonds for revivify as long as they have the equivalent gold). This can ease the finality of death but may lessen the perceived risks if resurrection is too easy.
Lasting Scars or Injuries: Instead of death, a character who drops to zero hit points survives with a lasting scar or injury, adding depth to their story. This provides consequences without removing the character from the game, balancing risk and continuity.
Balancing Risk and Reward: Ensure that death has meaningful consequences to encourage thoughtful play. If consequences are too severe, players may become overly cautious; if too light, they may act recklessly.
DM QuestionHow should we handle character death and resurrection to balance the risks and consequences in our game? Considerations:
Maintaining meaningful consequences for risky actions.
Avoiding overly harsh penalties that discourage engagement.
Preventing reckless behavior due to negligible consequences.
Keeping the game fun and the story impactful. Options:
Use standard rules: death saving throws and resurrection spells as written.
Characters become unconscious at zero hit points, with death occurring under specific conditions.
Allow for easier resurrection but introduce costs or side effects to maintain stakes.
Implement lasting scars or injuries as consequences of dropping to zero hit points.


DM QuestionIs food and drink welcome at the table during sessions? Is alcohol?

DM QuestionWhat are our expectations regarding smartphones and electronic devices at the table? Options:
Allowed for game-related use only.
Permitted freely.
Minimized to avoid distractions.
Turned off or silenced during sessions.

DM QuestionHow much time should we spend checking rules during the game? Options:
All rules must be followed so time is no option!
Limit to a few minutes per instance.
Make a best guess and check after the session.

DM QuestionWhat style of role-playing does the group prefer? Options:
In-depth role-playing like Critical Role.
Casual and light-hearted like Stranger Things.
A mix of both, depending on the situation.


As your DM, I prioritize storytelling and narrative flow. The rules of Dungeons & Dragons serve as a framework, but I may choose to ignore or override a rule in a particular scene to enhance the story or maintain pacing.

Rules as Guidelines: While I respect the rules, I may make on-the-spot decisions to keep the game moving smoothly.
Open to Input: If you notice a rule that might have been overlooked, please bring it to my attention. Often, it may be an oversight.
Final Decisions: If I acknowledge a rule and decide to intentionally ignore it for narrative reasons, I'd appreciate if we can proceed without further debate during the session.
DM QuestionAre you comfortable with a story-driven approach where rules might be adjusted for narrative purposes?

While storytelling is a priority, the rules are still important for fairness and consistency.

Rule Discussions: If there's a disagreement about a rule, we can briefly discuss it, but I may make a final decision to keep the game moving.
Post-Session Clarifications: For complex rule questions, we can delve deeper after the session to find a solution that works for everyone.
DM QuestionAre you agreeable to addressing detailed rule discussions after the session to maintain game flow?

I enjoy involving players in the creation of the game's narrative and world details.
DM DesirePlayers take a proactive approach to help advancing plot element.

Player Contributions: I may ask you to add details to a scene or describe elements that your character notices.
Example: “There's a mob of zombies—they're rotting villagers! Describe one of the zombies that draws your attention.”
Enhancing Engagement: This approach helps give you a concrete investment in the scene and enriches the story with ideas I might not have considered.
Option to Pass: If you're not comfortable or prefer not to be put on the spot, you can always say "Pass."
DM QuestionAre you comfortable contributing to scene descriptions and participating in collaborative storytelling?

Dungeons & Dragons gameplay is often divided among three main pillars: Exploration, Social Interaction, and Combat. Understanding your preferences helps me tailor the campaign to ensure everyone is engaged and enjoying the game.

Exploration: Discovering new places, solving puzzles, and overcoming environmental challenges.
Social Interaction: Engaging with NPCs, negotiating, and role-playing conversations.
Combat: Tactical battles, strategy, and action-packed encounters.
DM QuestionWhat is your preferred balance among the three pillars of gameplay: Exploration, Social Interaction, and Combat? Options:
A balanced mix of all three.
More focus on [Exploration/Social Interaction/Combat].
Less emphasis on [Exploration/Social Interaction/Combat].
Flexible, open to any balance as long as the story is engaging.

Lines and Veils are tools used to establish boundaries within our game to ensure that all players feel comfortable and safe. They help define which topics are acceptable, which should be approached with discretion, and which should be avoided entirely.

Lines are hard boundaries—subjects that players do not want to be included in the game under any circumstances. These topics should not be brought up at all, even in passing.
Veils are softer boundaries—subjects that can be part of the story but are kept in soft focus or occur off-camera. These elements might be mentioned or implied but are not described in detail.
It's the difference between "this doesn't come up at all" and "this may be a part of the plot but treated with some discretion."
Understanding each other's Lines and Veils allows us to create a respectful and enjoyable gaming experience for everyone. It's important to discuss these boundaries openly and honestly.


Line Example: A player may state, "I don't want cruelty to animals to feature in this game at all, even as a scene-setting detail." This means the DM and other players should avoid introducing this element entirely.
Veil Example: A player may state, "I'd be OK with someone mentioning a horse looking overworked or a dog looking neglected and hungry to show how bad things are but I don't want a scene of the villain kicking puppies specifically." This means the DM and other players be careful with how they approach the topic.
Even after setting initial Lines and Veils, it's crucial to remain open to further discussions. Sometimes, you might not realize a topic is uncomfortable until it arises during gameplay.
DM Questions
Are there any topics or themes that are Lines for you - subjects you do not want included in the game at all?
Are there any topics or themes that are Veils for you — subjects you're okay with as long as they are handled discreetly?
What is your preferred way of addressing new boundaries that might arise during gameplay?

item.title: 1. Welcome to Eberron
item.description:
Welcome to Eberron, a world of magic woven into the fabric of daily life where airships soar between towered cities, lightning rails race across continents, and elemental power fuels industry and innovation. But this is also a land scarred by a century of war, where fragile truces barely hold the nations together, and shadows of the Last War loom large. Intrigue, danger, and moral ambiguity define the world, where dragonmarked dynasties hold power rivaling nations, and nothing is ever as simple as it seems. This is a place where adventure awaits, and your choices will shape the future.
Let's explore what makes Eberron a unique setting for our adventure


In Eberron, magic isn't something reserved for mysterious wizards or rare moments of wonder. No, here magic powers the world itself. Picture this: vast cities where the streets are lit not by mundane flames, but by everbright lanterns—arcane lights that never flicker, never fade. Look up, and you’ll see airships drifting lazily between towers that scrape the sky, their bound elementals crackling with energy. Beneath your feet, lightning rails zip across the continent, powered by elemental forces as passengers travel at speeds undreamed of elsewhere. This is Eberron—where magic isn’t just something you study, it’s something you live with every day.
But this isn’t your typical fantasy magic—it’s an integral part of life, almost like technology in our world. Magewrights, specialists in small but essential spells, use magic to craft fine items, maintain city infrastructure, and even breed magical animals. In the forges of House Cannith, ancient magic is combined with ingenuity to produce wonders like the warforged—living constructs made of wood and steel, given life and sentience to serve as soldiers during the Last War.
In Eberron, magic shapes everything. It builds the cities, fuels the economy, and created beings like the warforged, who are still searching for their place in a world that once needed them for destruction but now must find a way to live with them in peace. Magic, in Eberron, is both a tool for progress and a force of disruption. It’s everywhere, in everything, and it’s waiting for you to tap into its wonders—or its dangers.


In Eberron, nothing is quite as it seems. Here, the lines between good and evil blur, and the world is steeped in moral ambiguity. Imagine a place where the most noble hero might be forced to make dark, questionable decisions, and even the brightest lights cast the deepest shadows. This is a world of intrigue and noir, where corruption festers beneath the surface and powerful organizations pull the strings behind the scenes. In Eberron, good and evil aren’t just black and white—they’re shaped by culture, circumstance, and personal ambition.
One of the most striking differences in Eberron is that traditional alignments don’t always apply in the way you might expect. That gold dragon you meet? It may not be the benevolent sage you're used to. It could have its own selfish or even destructive agenda. The orc you encounter might be a paragon of law and virtue, and the drow lurking in the shadows may be no more dangerous than the humans from Aundair. In Eberron, morality is fluid. A person’s actions are not defined by the color of their skin or the shape of their body, but by their choices, their experiences, and their ambitions.
That doesn’t mean evil doesn’t exist—it’s everywhere. But the evil you’ll encounter in Eberron isn’t always a cackling villain twirling a mustache. Instead, it might be the kindly innkeeper who shorts her customers to pad her own pocket, or the guard who takes bribes to let criminals through the gate. You might even meet a crusading paladin of the Silver Flame—someone who fights for righteousness—but who crosses lines, like zealously hunting down heretics with no regard for collateral damage.
The reality is that evil in Eberron often looks like selfishness, greed, and a willingness to harm others for personal gain. The mage who sacrifices innocents in the name of a cure, the spy who tortures for information—these are people who see their actions as necessary, even righteous. In this world, your decisions may not just be about right and wrong—they may be about what you’re willing to live with, or who you’re willing to trust in a place where trust is a rare and precious thing.
So, as you explore Eberron, remember that the classic rules don’t always apply. Fiends might offer genuine help, dragons may pursue their own agendas, and allies could become your greatest enemies. Your choices will carry weight, and the consequences will ripple across the world in ways you never expected. In Eberron, nothing is ever simple—and that’s what makes it so captivating.


Eberron is a world where high adventure collides with a sense of constant danger. It’s a place where you’ll leap from the deck of an airship as it crashes in flames, chase down enemies on the speeding lightning rail, and battle mad cultists in the shadowy depths of ancient ruins. It’s a world that embraces the excitement and action of pulp fiction—filled with bold heroes, sinister villains, and impossible odds.
Imagine the sprawling jungles of Xen'drik, a continent teeming with mysteries from lost civilizations. Here, dark elves ride giant scorpions and hurl metal boomerangs with deadly precision, while deep within, forgotten ruins hide treasures and powers beyond imagining. Or perhaps you find yourself racing across Khorvaire on the lightning rail, your foes closing in as the train rockets toward its destination, suspended above the ground by arcs of elemental energy. And above it all, airships powered by bound elementals sail across the sky—if you’re lucky, you’ll end up fighting on one of these, and if you’re really lucky, you’ll survive.
But it’s not just about exotic locations and thrilling action. Eberron is home to mad cultists plotting to unleash the chaos of the Dragon Below, crazy wizards studying the shifting planes as they await the right celestial conjunction to power their infernal machines, and more than a few shadowy organizations all vying for world domination. Everywhere you go, there’s the potential for high-stakes encounters, grand spectacles, and dangerous schemes.
At the heart of it all is the Draconic Prophecy—a cosmic puzzle woven into the fabric of the world itself. Dragons, immortals, and fiends all seek to interpret its secrets, believing they can shape the future to their will. But the Prophecy doesn’t predict a single destiny. It shows countless possible futures, all shaped by the choices of mortals like you. Every action, every decision, could shift the balance of power in ways you can’t yet imagine.
In Eberron, you’re not just an adventurer—you’re a hero in a world teetering on the edge. Your strength, skill, and courage will be tested at every turn, but so will your wits and your heart. Whether you’re leaping from crashing airships, battling evil cults in forgotten ruins, or outwitting ancient dragons, every moment in Eberron is filled with excitement, danger, and the chance to make your mark on a world where nothing is ever quite what it seems.
And remember—remarkable heroes often find themselves up against equally remarkable villains. You’ll face rivals who match your strength, villains who return after seeming death with vengeance on their minds, and shadowy figures whose plans stretch across entire nations. Every victory will push your foes to grow stronger, forcing you to rise to meet the challenge. Welcome to the pulp adventure of Eberron, where the stakes are always high, and the only way out is through.

In Eberron, true power lies not just in crowns and swords, but in the dragonmarked houses—ancient dynasties whose bloodlines bear magical sigils known as dragonmarks. These marks aren’t tattoos; they’re living magic, granting unique abilities to those lucky enough to manifest them. Imagine heirs with the Mark of Healing, raising the dead for House Jorasco, or airship pilots of House Lyrandar, controlling the skies with the Mark of Storms.

These houses run like powerful corporations, monopolizing industries across Khorvaire. If you need healing, travel, or banking, you’ll deal with one of these houses. Their influence rivals that of entire nations, and their reach is everywhere—from cities to wilderness. Even independent businesses often bear their approval, showing the sheer control they hold over commerce.
Dragonmarks appear during adolescence, but not every heir receives one. Those who do gain prestige, adding the 'd’ prefix to their names, becoming part of an elite force that shapes Eberron’s future. Yet the dragonmarked houses are filled with intrigue—some heirs are exiled, called excoriates, while foundlings possess marks without the backing of the powerful families.
Once kept in check by the Korth Edicts, the houses’ power has only grown since the Last War. Now, they push the limits of their influence, with some wondering if they’ll ever be stopped. For adventurers like you, the dragonmarked houses offer both opportunity and danger. Aligning with them could bring wealth and power, but crossing them could mean your downfall.
The marks and their houses are,

House Medani (Mark of Detection): Masters of uncovering hidden threats, specializing in risk assessment, protection, and community service over power.
House Tharashk (Mark of Finding): Experts in tracking, bounty hunting, and dragonshard prospecting, driven by the unified strength of human and half-orc clans.
House Vadalis (Mark of Handling): Masters of breeding and training animals, from mundane beasts to magical creatures like hippogriffs, with rumors of even more ambitious magebreeding experiments.
House Jorasco (Mark of Healing): Renowned healers who can cure the sick and even pull souls back from death—at a price—while rumors persist of darker experiments conducted during the Last War.
House Ghallanda (Mark of Hospitality): Masters of comfort and connection, Ghallanda halflings run inns, taverns, and sanctuaries across the Five Nations, offering both hospitality and quiet influence through a network of bound favors and well-placed allies.
House Cannith (Mark of Making): Masters of creation, House Cannith controls the manufacture of weapons, warforged, and magical goods, but the house is fractured—three rival barons vie for leadership after the Mourning devastated their ancestral seat in Cyre.
House Orien (Mark of Passage): Masters of transportation, House Orien controls the lightning rail and overland caravans, but faces growing challenges from the Mournland's destruction and the rise of Lyrandar airships.
House Sivis (Mark of Scribing): House Sivis, led by gnomes, masters communication—managing speaking stones and training scribes and interpreters. Neutral and discreet, they facilitate long-distance messages and notarize important documents with their arcane marks.
House Deneith (Mark of Sentinel): House Deneith, born of war, offers elite mercenaries, bodyguards, and law-enforcing Sentinel Marshals. Neutral yet powerful, they serve all sides while guarding their honor and keeping Khorvaire safe from danger.
The Houses of Shadow (Mark of Shadow): House Phiarlan and House Thuranni excel in illusion and espionage, wielding the Mark of Shadow to deceive, entertain, and assassinate. Though split by a bitter feud, the houses remain unmatched as spies and artists, sculpting secrets from the shadows of Khorvaire.
House Lyrandar (Mark of Storm): Masters of wind and sea, House Lyrandar uses the Mark of Storm to command weather and elemental vessels, ruling both maritime trade and the skies with their airships, while their island enclave, Stormhome, stands as their sanctuary and seat of power.
House Kundarak (Mark of Warding): Guardians of wealth and security, House Kundarak wields the Mark of Warding to protect valuables with mystic locks and wards, operating both a vast banking network and the infamous Dreadhold prison, renowned for its legendary security and extradimensional vaults.

The Last War may have ended, but its shadow looms large over Eberron. For a century, the Five Nations fought a brutal conflict that shattered the kingdom of Galifar. Though the Treaty of Thronehold declared peace, it’s a fragile one, held together by fear and uncertainty. The Mourning—an inexplicable cataclysm that obliterated Cyre in a single day—serves as a chilling reminder of the devastation that unchecked power can wreak. The land of Cyre is now a twisted wasteland known as the Mournland, a scar on the continent of Khorvaire, haunted by undead and living spells that still roam the battlefield.
The atmosphere in Eberron echoes the tensions of post-World War I Europe. Soldiers return home unsure of their place in a world at peace. Nations eye each other with suspicion, their leaders quietly preparing for the inevitable return of conflict. Magic-driven war machines and weapons of incredible power litter the landscape, remnants of a war that never really ended in the hearts and minds of the people.
The warforged, living constructs created for battle, now walk free—granted citizenship by the treaty that ended the war. But for many, peace is an uncomfortable fit. Warforged were designed for a world at war, and many struggle to find their place in a society that fears them as tools of destruction with no purpose beyond combat.
The Mourning stands at the heart of every conversation about the future. Was it an accident? A weapon gone wrong? Or something far worse, still waiting to be unleashed? Fear of the Mourning keeps the nations in check, but for how long? Everyone knows that peace in Eberron is temporary—the Last War may have paused, but few believe it’s truly over.
The world of Eberron is waiting for you—full of mystery, magic, and adventure. What will you make of it?

item.title: 2. Eberron's History
item.description:
Long before the rise of mortals or the first breath of history, the world of Eberron was shaped by forces as old as existence itself. According to myth, three Progenitor Dragons—Siberys, Eberron, and Khyber—wove the fabric of the planes, bringing the universe into being. Their creation was a perfect balance of light and shadow, order and chaos, life and death. But harmony was fleeting. Khyber, driven by ambition and darkness, betrayed Siberys, striking him down and scattering his golden essence across the sky as the Ring of Siberys. To contain this evil, Eberron coiled herself around Khyber, imprisoning the dark force within her coils and becoming the very world itself—the living, breathing planet you now call home. Thus, the Dragon Above, the Dragon Between, and the Dragon Below define the very essence of Eberron, their legacy etched into the land, sky, and the shadows beneath.
Though many cultures consider this story a myth, it resonates across the world, with Siberys embodying the sky and magic, Eberron as the life-giving earth, and Khyber as the dark underworld, filled with aberrations and fiends. The tale of their cosmic struggle remains a foundation of Eberron’s lore, with its influence still felt today in the world’s magic, natural forces, and the terrifying creatures that dwell deep below.

The rise and fall of great civilizations mark the mortal history of Eberron.


Over 100,000 years ago, Eberron was ruled by the dark children of Khyber—fiends, aberrations, and monsters that rose from the depths. Among them were the Overlords, thirty immortal archfiends who shaped the world to their malevolent desires. For millennia, these fiends reigned supreme, bending reality itself to their will. No civilization could stand against them.
But the tide of this dark era shifted when the Sovereign Host, along with an alliance of dragons and the celestial couatl, rose to challenge the overlords. The war that followed saw untold sacrifice, with the couatl binding the archfiends into eternal prisons using their own life force, creating the Silver Flame, a power that endures to this day. Though the overlords are bound, their influence still lingers, and those who seek to free them—like the Lords of Dust—work in the shadows, ensuring that the struggle against these ancient evils never truly ends.


Around 80,000 years ago, the giants of Xen'drik rose to power, unlocking secrets of arcane magic that still surpass modern understanding. In their prime, these giant civilizations achieved incredible feats, binding elementals and creating eldritch machines of immense power. But their reach extended too far. When a war broke out between the giants and the quori of Dal Quor, the giants ended the conflict by destroying one of Eberron's moons, severing Dal Quor's link to the world.
This victory came at a terrible cost. Uprisings followed, most notably by the elves, who had long been enslaved by the giants. As the giants prepared to unleash catastrophic magic to crush the rebellion, the dragons intervened, emerging from Argonnessen to shatter the once-great civilizations of Xen'drik. They laid powerful curses upon the land, ensuring that no great empire could ever rise again. These draconic curses—such as the Traveler's Curse and Du’rashka Tul—warp space, twist minds, and keep Xen'drik a land of perilous, ever-shifting wilderness.


The Age of Monsters was dominated by the rise and fall of mighty civilizations on Khorvaire, especially the goblinoid Empire of Dhakaan, which flourished for over ten thousand years. From around 16,000 years ago, Dhakaan spread across central Khorvaire, pushing other races—dwarves, dragonborn, and orcs—to the continent's margins. But it wasn’t the only power shaping the land. After fleeing the destruction of Xen'drik, elves settled on Aerenal, around 25,000 years ago, forming the mystical Undying Court and the warrior tradition of the Tairnadal.
The Dhakaani Empire faced its greatest challenge around 9,000 years ago, with the invasion of the daelkyr, who led armies of aberrations from the plane of Xoriat. Though the Gatekeeper druids and Dhakaani champions ultimately sealed the daelkyr in Khyber, the damage was done. Madness crept through the goblinoid ranks, eroding the unity of their civilization. By 5,000 years ago, the empire crumbled into ruin and civil war, leaving behind scattered remnants of their once-great culture.
Today, Dhakaani ruins lie beneath many modern cities, and adventurers often explore these forgotten halls. The daelkyr’s influence persists as well, manifesting in the Cults of the Dragon Below and the Gatekeeper druids who continue to guard against aberrant threats. This ancient history still shapes the present, as goblins and orcs in places like Darguun seek to reclaim the glory of their fallen empire, while dwarves in the Mror Holds unearth strange relics from the lost Realm Below.


In the wake of the Age of Monsters, a new era began across Khorvaire—one that saw the rise of humanity and the discovery of the first dragonmarks. Scholars debate whether this era should be called the Age of Humanity or the Dragonmarked Age, as both human civilizations and the dragonmarked houses came into power. This era saw humanity spread from Sarlona to Khorvaire, where they established powerful city-states. During this time, the foundation for the Five Nations was laid, marking the early history of Galifar and the dominance of humans over the continent.

Key events include the arrival of human settlers led by the adventurer Lhazaar, who established the Lhazaar Principalities around 3,000 years ago. Simultaneously, the first dragonmarks began to manifest, including the Mark of Hospitality among the halflings of the Talenta Plains and the Mark of Death among the elves of Aerenal. The elves soon faced tragedy as the Undying Court and dragons from Argonnessen annihilated the House of Vol, bearers of the Mark of Death, due to their dangerous experiments in combining elven and draconic magic.
By 2,500 years ago, human city-states like Korth, Metrol, and Wroat had risen to prominence, marking the early stages of what would become the Five Nations of Galifar. The discovery of dragonmarks continued, with the Mark of Making appearing in Metrol, and the Mark of Warding among the dwarves of the Ironroot Mountains. Giants and goblinoid civilizations receded further, their power diminished by human expansion. This growth led to conflicts, such as Karrn the Conqueror's failed attempts to unify Khorvaire under Karrnath, establishing centuries-long power struggles.
This time also saw the emergence of new races, including the kalashtar in Adar, formed by monks who voluntarily bound their spirits to the quori, creating a powerful new lineage. New cultures, such as the Venomous Demesne in modern Droaam, emerged from refugee tiefling and human settlements escaping Sarlona’s upheavals.


The War of the Mark was a dark chapter in Eberron’s history, marking the near-extinction of those with aberrant dragonmarks—strange and dangerous powers feared by the populace. Around 1,500 years ago, when the dragonmarked houses joined together as the Twelve, they turned their influence against those with aberrant marks. Propaganda stoked fear, casting the aberrant-marked as uncontrollable threats to society. Though many were innocent, they became scapegoats in a purge led by House Deneith soldiers, Vadalis trackers, and Medani inquisitors.
The war culminated in the rise of powerful champions like Halas Tarkanan and the Lady of the Plague, who made their final stand in Sharn, declaring it a haven for the persecuted. When defeat became inevitable, Tarkanan used his mark to shatter the city's towers, while the Lady unleashed diseases and vermin, destroying both the city and their enemies. Sharn lay in ruins for centuries afterward, a testament to the war’s devastation.
Though the aberrant marks were nearly eradicated, fear and prejudice endured. In recent years, aberrant marks have begun to reappear with growing frequency and power, raising concerns of another purge. Today, the secretive House Tarkanan trains those with aberrant marks, preparing for the possibility of a renewed conflict with the Twelve.


The Kingdom of Galifar stands as a golden age in the history of Khorvaire, an era of peace, progress, and unity. Founded in 1 YK by Galifar Wynarn, the kingdom unified the Five Nations not only through military might but also through diplomacy and a vision of a better world. Under Galifar’s rule, slavery was abolished, justice was reformed, and public education flourished, paving the way for the rise of the merchant class and economic stability. The Arcane Congress, Rekkenmark Academy, and other key institutions were established to serve the common good, fostering an age of advancement.
However, Galifar's reign wasn't without flaws. His policy of allowing the dragonmarked houses to dominate certain industries planted the seeds of their immense modern power, leading to near-monopolies that the Korth Edicts only partially curtailed. Additionally, his precarious system of succession—where his children ruled as governors of the Five Nations—sowed the seeds of discord. While this kept the realm stable for nearly nine centuries, it led to numerous rebellions and secessions over the kingdom's history, culminating in the Last War.
Despite its eventual downfall in 894 YK, the legacy of Galifar endures. The common laws, institutions, and cultural norms shared across the Five Nations are all remnants of that united past. Even after a century of brutal conflict, many still yearn for the golden age of Galifar and believe that true peace and unity can only be achieved by restoring the kingdom.


The Silver Crusade began as a response to a rising tide of lycanthropy that threatened the western regions of Aundair. Once considered a rare and fearful legend, lycanthropy suddenly grew more virulent and dangerous during the early ninth century, with werewolf attacks and wererat infestations spreading fear and chaos. By 832 YK, the Keeper of the Flame, Jolan Sol, declared lycanthropy a corrupting force that needed to be eradicated, leading the Church of the Silver Flame to launch a brutal fifty-year campaign against the lycanthropes. The first two decades were particularly bloody as templars fought a losing battle against growing hordes of lycanthropes, many of whom were thought to be driven by the influence of a near-freed overlord. However, through decades of conflict, the templars eventually broke the power of the curse, weakening lycanthropy across Khorvaire.
Though the templars succeeded in weakening the lycanthropic threat, the Silver Crusade did not end without controversy. The final thirty years saw an ongoing inquisition led by a zealous sect known as the Pure Flame. They sought to purge every last lycanthrope but also targeted innocent shifters and other suspected werecreatures. The Pure Flame's actions created lasting rifts between the followers of the Silver Flame and the shifter communities, particularly in the Eldeen Reaches. While the Silver Crusade began as an effort to protect the people, it ended as a dark chapter of paranoia and hatred.
The Crusade's aftermath left a lasting mark on Eberron, with lycanthropy now treated as a serious public health risk. Templars of the Silver Flame are still charged with dealing with lycanthropes, though they often seek to cure rather than kill, except when necessary. Meanwhile, lycanthropes have found havens in places like Droaam and Stormreach, and the scars of the crusade still affect shifters across the continent.


The Last War was a century-long conflict that shattered the once-united kingdom of Galifar and forever altered the landscape of Khorvaire. After the death of King Jarot in 894 YK, a bitter struggle for succession erupted between his children, plunging the Five Nations into open war. What began as a civil war soon spiraled into a vast and brutal conflict, marked by shifting alliances, political intrigue, and grueling battles. Magic and military innovation fueled the war, giving rise to devastating new weapons and war machines, such as the warforged, constructs created to serve as soldiers in the endless conflict.
The war reached its darkest moment on 20 Olarune 994 YK with the Day of Mourning, when the nation of Cyre was obliterated by a mysterious magical cataclysm. The Mourning left behind the Mournland, a twisted wasteland filled with living spells and undead horrors, and claimed over a million lives in a single day. The shock of the Mourning forced the warring nations to the negotiating table, and the conflict came to a fragile end with the signing of the Treaty of Thronehold in 996 YK. Although the war is over, no one claims victory, and many believe that it is only a matter of time before hostilities reignite.


Though the Treaty of Thronehold brought a formal end to the Last War, Khorvaire remains a continent on edge. The scars of the war are everywhere—cities lie in ruins, forests and farmlands are scorched, and refugees from Cyre wander the land, homeless and destitute. The Mourning haunts the continent, with many fearing that its destructive power could return or be harnessed as a weapon. This fear keeps the fragile peace in place, but few believe that it will last.
Nations continue to jockey for position, eyeing their neighbors with suspicion while secretly rebuilding their military forces. The rise of new powers, such as the Valenar elves and the goblins of Darguun, further complicates the political landscape. Meanwhile, the dragonmarked houses, having profited enormously during the war, now wield unprecedented power, controlling vital industries such as transportation, banking, and healing. The warforged, once mere tools of war, now walk free, struggling to find their place in a world that once needed them only for battle.
As of 998 YK, two years after the war's end, the continent stands at a crossroads. Peace is fragile, and every nation is making preparations for the possibility of future conflict. The mystery of the Mourning looms large, and while some seek to understand its origins, others prepare for its potential return. The Last War may be over, but its shadow lingers across Eberron, and the wounds of the past are far from healed.

item.title: 3. Eberron's Places
item.description:
https://eberronmap.johnarcadian.com/
The world of Eberron is vast, diverse, and full of wonders, spanning multiple continents, each with its own distinct cultures, peoples, and dangers.

Khorvaire: The starting stage of adventures is Khorvaire, the largest and most populous continent. It is a land rich in history, industry, and intrigue—home to towering cities, ancient ruins, and the scars of war. Khorvaire is the heart of the Five Nations, and it is where the Last War unfolded, reshaping the continent forever. Once the unified Kingdom of Galifar, this continent is now a fractured land of independent nations. From the sprawling metropolis of Sharn, the City of Towers, to the icy plains of Karrnath, the lightning rail routes of Breland, and the magical academies of Aundair, Khorvaire is the center of politics, trade, and conflict in Eberron.
Xen'drik: Southwest of Khorvaire lies Xen'drik, a vast jungle continent filled with ancient ruins and the remnants of the once-great giant civilizations. This land is shrouded in mystery and danger. Adventurers come here seeking treasure, lost magic, and the hidden secrets of the giant empire, but they must contend with the wild, unpredictable magic of the land, and the deadly creatures that call Xen'drik home.
Aerenal: South of Khorvaire lies Aerenal, an island continent ruled by the immortal elves. Here, the elves worship their undying ancestors, who guide their society from beyond death. The island is steeped in ancient magic, with the elves guarding the arcane secrets they’ve accumulated over millennia. Aerenal remains isolated from much of the world, its people focused inward, guarding their ancient rites and secrets.
Argonnessen: Far to the southeast, Argonnessen is the land of dragons, a place forbidden to most mortals. Here, dragons dwell in ancient cities, studying the Draconic Prophecy and guarding secrets that could reshape the world. Few who travel to Argonnessen ever return, and those who do are often forever changed by what they’ve seen.
Sarlona: Across the eastern sea lies the continent of Sarlona, the original birthplace of humanity. Though once home to a multitude of kingdoms, today, the continent is largely dominated by the Inspired—psionic rulers of the Riedran Empire, who command armies of psychic warriors and enforce strict control over their people. Beneath the surface, the Kalashtar—a race of psionically gifted humans bound to spiritual entities called quori—quietly wage a resistance against the Inspired.
Let's take a deeper look at when we'll be starting

+−0 milesLeaflet
Khorvaire is the continent where most adventures in Eberron begin—a land rich in history, magic, and intrigue. Thanks to the tireless efforts of House Sivis and House Orien, Khorvaire is well-mapped and connected, making it the most navigable of Eberron’s continents. However, even though many regions are well-known, there are still uncharted corners filled with ancient secrets, wild dangers, and mysteries waiting to be uncovered.

Humans make up the majority of Khorvaire’s population, but this diverse continent is home to a wide array of cultures, races, and creatures. Once united under the Kingdom of Galifar, Khorvaire is now divided into various nations, some as old as history itself, others forged in the crucible of the Last War. While peace reigns for now, the scars of the war are still fresh, and tensions simmer just beneath the surface.
Khorvaire’s Nations are connected by a well-maintained system of roads, along with the lightning rail of House Orien that spans the central nations, allowing swift travel between major cities. For those with deeper pockets, the airships of House Lyrandar offer the fastest, albeit most expensive, means of travel. Whether by land, rail, or air, Khorvaire’s network of transportation keeps its fractured nations tied together, though rivalries and suspicions remain strong.

Everyday life in Khorvaire reflects the continent’s complexity. The lingering effects of the Last War, the dominance of the dragonmarked houses, and the omnipresence of magic all shape the culture of its nations.

Khorvaire's vast population is multilingual, with Common serving as the trade language and most widely spoken tongue. However, regional languages like Dwarvish in the Mror Holds, Giant in Xen'drik, and Goblin in Darguun and the Shadow Marches reflect the deep history of the continent. The naming conventions of Khorvaire also vary by region and culture, with nobles adding the "ir'" prefix to their family names, and dragonmarked heirs using the "d'" prefix to signify their status.

The common calendar of Khorvaire is based on the twelve moons of Eberron, with each month corresponding to the closest moon. The timeline begins with the foundation of the Kingdom of Galifar, measured in YK (Years of the Kingdom). By default, most campaigns in Khorvaire begin in the year 998 YK, just two years after the Treaty of Thronehold ended the Last War, though the continent remains on edge.

Trade and commerce in Khorvaire are built on a stable system of currency established during the Galifar era. Coins such as the gold galifar (gp), silver sovereign (sp), and copper crown (cp) are still used across the nations, ensuring a standardized economy. Wealthy merchants and nobles often use letters of credit backed by the bankers of the Mror Holds, while common folk still use coins for day-to-day transactions.

Let’s explore each country a little more, moving from west to east, though not in any particular order of importance. Keep in mind that the original empire, Galifar, which was shattered by the Last War, consisted of five core nations: Aundair, Thrane, Breland, Cyre, and Karrnath. These are still referred to as the Five Nations, and their legacy continues to shape the politics and culture of Khorvaire today.

The Shadow Marches are a desolate, swampy region filled with moors and mystery, home to the largest half-orc population in Khorvaire. Though not a formal nation, the Marches are primarily known for their rich deposits of Eberron dragonshards, making them a hub for prospectors. The orcs and humans here live in isolated tribes, with a long history tied to the ancient struggle against the daelkyr, aberrant creatures who left behind madness and twisted monsters in the swamps. House Tharashk, a half-orc house known for the Mark of Finding, dominates the region's commerce through Zarash’ak, their unofficial capital. The Shadow Marches are also the birthplace of the Gatekeepers, a druidic sect that continues to protect the land from extraplanar threats, though dangerous cults and daelkyr relics still linger in the shadows.

A monstrous nation ruled by the Daughters of Sora Kell, Droaam is a land where creatures like ogres, trolls, harpies, gnolls, and medusas thrive. Formed just over a decade ago, this wild territory west of the Graywall Mountains has quickly gained strength and stability under the hags' leadership, despite not being recognized by the Treaty of Thronehold. Its capital, the Great Crag, is growing, along with the frontier cities like Graywall. House Tharashk partners with Droaam to export monstrous mercenaries and the rare byeshk ore. Though most of Khorvaire dismisses Droaam as a temporary alliance, the nation's power continues to rise, making the rest of the continent uneasy.

The Demon Wastes is a desolate and dangerous region, where rivers of lava cut through blackened plains and volcanic glass. Once home to powerful fiends and ancient demon lords, this cursed land is now inhabited by fiends, including devils, rakshasas, and demons, as well as the brutal Carrion Tribes, who worship these dark powers. The only barrier keeping these evils from spreading is the Labyrinth, a series of canyons patrolled by the Ghaash'kala, a tribe of orcs sworn to contain the horrors of the Wastes. Though its ruins may hold ancient treasures, the Demon Wastes remain a deadly and treacherous place where few dare to venture.

The Eldeen Reaches are a vast, loosely governed region of fertile farmlands and the untamed Towering Wood. Once part of Aundair, the farmers of eastern Aundair seceded during the Last War with the help of druids and rangers, forming their own nation. The Reaches are home to a diverse population, including humans, shifters, and nomadic druidic circles. The Wardens of the Wood, the largest druid sect, maintain peace and harmony, guided by the Great Druid, an awakened greatpine named Oalian. Known for agriculture and animal husbandry, the Reaches blend natural magic into everyday life, where druids advise communities, and awakened beasts and fey creatures are part of the society. Although peaceful, the Reachers remain wary of Aundair and prepare for a possible conflict to defend their independence.

Aundair is a kingdom steeped in magic, ruled by the ambitious Queen Aurala ir’Wynarn. Known for its arcane prowess, Aundair is home to the prestigious magical academy of Arcanix, and the floating towers that symbolize its mastery over wizardry. The majority of its population consists of humans, with half-elves and elves often found among the nation’s scholars and nobles. Dwarves and gnomes also contribute to the kingdom’s vibrant academic and artistic communities. Aundairians value knowledge, finesse, and fashion, and their land is known for producing fine wines, cheeses, and grain. Despite its small size, Aundair held its own in the Last War through superior magical power. However, tensions linger with both Thrane and the Eldeen Reaches, and many Aundairians still seek to reclaim lost territories. Magic permeates everyday life, and Aundair's elegant culture stands in stark contrast to the scars left by the war.

Thrane is a human theocracy ruled by the Church of the Silver Flame, with 11-year-old Jaela Daran as the divine Keeper of the Flame. The Silver Flame’s purpose is to defend the innocent from supernatural threats, making Thrane a beacon of faith and righteousness. While the faith is central, not all Thranes uphold its ideals—zealots seek to unite Khorvaire under the Flame, while corrupt priests pursue power. The nation is home to many clerics and paladins, though magewrights and wizards are less common. Thrane’s deep faith unites its people, but its strict adherence to the Silver Flame also fosters distrust toward necromancers, warlocks, and practitioners of dark magic.

Ruled by the popular King Boranel, Breland is a powerful and industrialized nation, known for its pragmatism, innovation, and intrigue. It boasts one of the most diverse populations in Khorvaire, with humans, half-elves, and halflings making up the majority, while its cities—especially Sharn—also welcome a variety of monstrous races, including goblins, ogres, orcs, and even harpies and gargoyles from nearby Droaam. Breland's large population and vast resources make it a hub of industry and espionage, but also a hotbed for organized crime. The nation played a significant role in the Last War and is home to the largest number of Cyran refugees. Though King Boranel remains beloved, some citizens advocate for a shift toward democracy once he passes, leaving Breland’s future uncertain.

Zilargo is the gnomish homeland, a peaceful-seeming paradise known for its brilliant minds, elemental binding, and fine alchemy. The Library of Korranberg, the largest repository of knowledge in Khorvaire, and the Korranberg Chronicle, the continent’s most popular newspaper, are based here. Despite the idyllic appearance, Zil society is a web of intrigue, with every gnome seemingly involved in one scheme or another. The Trust, a ruthless secret police force, eliminates threats to society with preemptive efficiency, ensuring the streets remain safe. As long as one follows the unwritten rules of Zil intrigue, life in Zilargo is serene—but crossing the Trust is a fatal mistake.

Darguun is a volatile and young nation ruled by the hobgoblin leader Lhesh Haruuc Sharaat'kor. Once part of Cyre, Darguun was seized during the Last War by the goblinoid mercenaries who had fought for the Five Nations. Now home to goblins, hobgoblins, and bugbears, the country is known for its fierce warriors and mercenary forces. While recognized as a nation under the Treaty of Thronehold, Darguun operates on its own terms, and its laws differ greatly from those of other treaty nations. Mercenaries, adventurers, and traders may find opportunities in this land, but it remains dangerous and unpredictable.

Once the shining heart of the Kingdom of Galifar, Cyre was obliterated by a magical cataclysm known as the Mourning. Now, the Mournland is a desolate wasteland of twisted magic and ghostly ruins, where wounds never heal and the dead do not decompose. Mutated monsters, living spells, and other strange dangers roam this cursed land, which remains largely uninhabited save for some warforged factions, including the enigmatic Lord of Blades. The survivors of Cyre, scattered across Khorvaire, dream of rebuilding their lost nation, though many simply strive to survive in a world that views them with a mix of pity and suspicion.

Karrnath is a grim and disciplined human kingdom ruled by King Kaius III, known for its military prowess and strict laws. During the Last War, the nation famously used undead troops—skeletons and zombies—raised by the necromancers of the Blood of Vol to bolster their armies. While the undead still serve as laborers and guards, Kaius has distanced himself from the Blood of Vol, creating tension between its followers and traditionalists who see the use of undead as a stain on Karrnath's honor. The people of Karrnath, predominantly humans with smaller populations of dwarves and half-elves, are tough and resilient, used to enduring harsh winters and strict rationing. Military training is a source of great pride, and the Rekkenmark Academy remains the premier institute for military officers. Though the war has ended, many Karrns still believe they would have won had it continued, and the nation remains on high alert, wary of unrest from within and without.

The Talenta Plains are home to the nomadic halflings, known for their close bond with the dinosaurs they ride and raise. These wild plains are vast, filled with roaming dinosaur herds and the halfling tribes that live off the land, following the guidance of their chieftains and shamans. Life here revolves around hunting, tradition, and a deep reverence for ancestral and natural spirits. While the halflings united under Lathon Halpum during the Last War to defend their way of life, they now face challenges as more outsiders cross the Plains, bringing both trade and conflict. Despite being recognized as a nation under the Treaty of Thronehold, the halflings must now decide if they will embrace change or push back against the encroaching influences.

Valenar is a land claimed by the warrior elves of Tairnadal during the Last War. Known for their unmatched cavalry and devotion to the arts of war, the Valenar elves took the region from Cyre, invoking ancient claims to the land. Their kingdom is primarily composed of open plains ideal for breeding their famous horses, with harsher environments like the Blade Desert serving as natural borders. Valenar elves live for battle and adventure, frequently patrolling their land in warbands or seeking challenges abroad. The daily affairs of the kingdom are managed by half-elves, while Cyran humans, the former inhabitants of the region, continue their lives under new rulers. Though Valenar is now a recognized sovereign nation, the elves remain focused on their next conflict, pushing the limits of peace as they seek worthy opponents.

A rugged frontier on the edge of Khorvaire, Q'barra was initially settled by those seeking refuge from the Last War, including loyalists to the old Galifar Empire and Cyran refugees. Its dense jungles and untamed wilderness hide both danger and opportunity. While human settlements are few, the region is rich with deposits of Eberron dragonshards, attracting prospectors, fortune-seekers, and criminals alike. Beneath the surface, however, Q'barra is home to ancient civilizations of lizardfolk and dragonborn, including the Cold Sun Federation and the hostile Poison Dusk tribes. Tensions between the settlers and the indigenous "scales" continue to rise, particularly as treaties are violated and settlers push deeper into lands tied to fiendish powers from the Age of Demons.

The mountainous home of the dwarves, the Mror Holds is a land of wealth and industry. Known for its vast metal mines and advanced metalwork, the dwarves of Mror have a reputation as master merchants and craftsmen. After discovering ancient dwarven ruins deep within the Ironroot Mountains, the clans uncovered riches and powerful artifacts, but also awakened an ancient evil: the daelkyr lord Dyrrn the Corruptor. Now, the dwarves battle aberrations in the depths of the Realm Below while continuing to mine its treasures. The Holds are a loose confederation of twelve noble clans, each governing a hold, but the threat of the daelkyr and differing views on how to deal with the aberrations—some clans embracing their power, others shunning it—threatens their unity.

The Lhazaar Principalities are a loose alliance of pirate lords, merchant princes, and sea barons who control the northeastern coastline of Khorvaire. Recognized as a nation under the Treaty of Thronehold, each island domain operates independently, often feuding with one another. The Lhazaar are the best sailors in Khorvaire, serving as privateers during the Last War and continuing piracy alongside legitimate merchant trade. Leadership is fluid, with anyone able to rise from sailor to prince through cunning and strength. High Prince Ryger ir'Wynarn of Regalport seeks to unite the principalities under his rule, but most princes value their independence. The Lhazaar Principalities also have a significant changeling population and a number of foundlings with the Mark of Storm, who are unaffiliated with House Lyrandar but seek to acquire airships for their own gain.

item.title: 4. Eberron's People
item.description:
Eberron is a diverse place where many different races coexist, each bringing unique cultures, histories, and abilities to the world. From the bustling cities of Khorvaire to the untamed frontiers, every race has carved out its place in the aftermath of the Last War. With the rise of dragonmarked houses and the ancient struggles of long-lost empires, the people of Eberron are shaped by their history and their roles in this complex and magical world.

Most of the races in Eberron have similarities to their standard counterparts in D&D, but there are notable differences that give them a unique flavor. Additionally, many races are tied to specific dragonmarks, which grant them special powers and influence over various industries and guilds across the continent.


Humans are the most common race in Eberron and are found in the majority of its kingdoms. They are versatile and ambitious, with some bearing dragonmarks that grant them great power. Humans can have the Mark of Finding, Mark of Handling, Mark of Making, Mark of Passage, or Mark of Sentinel, and they dominate most political, social, and economic landscapes, especially in the Five Nations.


In Eberron, half-elves are known as the Khoravar, a distinct race with their own culture. While they have some similarities to humans and elves, they stand apart with their unique identities. Half-elves can bear the Mark of Detection or the Mark of Storm, and many have positions of influence within their dragonmarked houses or serve as intermediaries between different cultures.


Half-orcs in Eberron trace their lineage back to ancient struggles with aberrant invaders from another plane. They often live in frontier areas, working as prospectors, trappers, or druids. Many have the Mark of Finding, which aids them in their search for dragonshards, valuable magical crystals scattered across Eberron.


Halflings in Eberron fall into two distinct categories. There are city-dwelling halflings who often work as innkeepers, healers, or merchants, using the Mark of Healing or Mark of Hospitality to support their work. Then there are the nomadic halflings of the Talenta Plains, who tame and ride dinosaurs, living a more primal and tribal lifestyle as fierce hunters and ambushers.


Gnomes in Eberron are known for their cunning and mastery of elemental binding, a vital magical technology. They play key roles in banking, magic, and politics, though much of their influence is kept secret. Gnomes can bear the Mark of Scribing, which enhances their roles as scribes, chroniclers, and agents of subterfuge. Their homeland, Zilargo, is a place of intrigue, hidden power, and conspiracy.


There are three main groups of elves in Eberron. The Aereni elves on the island of Aerenal revere their ancestors and maintain ancient traditions, with some serving the mysterious Undying Court. The Valenar elves are warrior nomads who staked a claim on Khorvaire during the Last War, renowned for their cavalry and martial skill. The Phiarlan and Thuranni elves bear the Mark of Shadow and run powerful guilds focusing on entertainment, espionage, and intrigue.


Dwarves in Eberron are master miners and craftsmen, living in powerful holds in the Mror Mountains. Their Mark of Warding allows them to excel in banking, defense, and protective magic. Dwarves also have a history of delving deep into the earth, uncovering both riches and ancient dangers, which have given rise to conflicts with powerful aberrations.

Changelings are shapeshifters, descendants of doppelgangers and humans, who can alter their appearance at will. This makes them natural spies, infiltrators, and diplomats, though their ability to hide in plain sight often leads to suspicion. Changelings never bear dragonmarks but are valued for their versatility and adaptability.

Shifters are the descendants of lycanthropes and humans, able to temporarily take on animalistic traits, such as growing claws, increasing speed, or heightening their senses. Shifters are often found in rural or wild areas, acting as rangers or hunters, and are closely tied to the natural world.

Warforged are living constructs, originally created to serve as soldiers during the Last War. Now that the war is over, they seek purpose beyond the battlefield, struggling with questions of identity and freedom. As sentient beings made of metal and magic, warforged don't need to eat or sleep, but they face widespread prejudice despite being granted full citizenship after the Treaty of Thronehold.

Dragonborn in Eberron trace their ancestry to Argonnessen, the homeland of dragons, though most in Khorvaire come from Q’barra, where they live alongside lizardfolk in the jungles. These dragonborn are believed to be descendants of an ancient empire and serve as guardians of their draconic heritage, with a deep connection to the Draconic Prophecy. Their society emphasizes honor, tradition, and service, and while they lack dragonmarks, their innate magic makes them powerful sorcerers and warriors. Some dragonborn venture out as mercenaries or explorers, seeking to unlock the secrets of their draconic legacy and protect the world from ancient threats.

Tieflings in Eberron descend from humans whose bloodlines were tainted by fiendish pacts, particularly those from the Venomous Demesne in Droaam, where ancient families fled the influence of demons and devils in Sarlona. While often viewed with suspicion due to their infernal ancestry, tieflings are not inherently evil, though their connection to dark magic is undeniable. Many tieflings become powerful sorcerers, warlocks, or rogues, using their fiendish heritage to gain power in a world that frequently distrusts them. Despite having no dragonmarks, their infernal bloodline grants them unique abilities, making them influential players in Eberron's politics and intrigue.

The population demographics of Khorvaire are diverse, though exact numbers are difficult to determine. No official census has ever been conducted, and the upheaval caused by the Last War further complicated matters. Scholars, however, have been able to estimate the rough distribution of species across the continent, excluding the underdark region known as Khyber and other continents like Aerenal. These estimates reflect only the known populations on Khorvaire itself and highlight the presence of both common races and the more exotic inhabitants of the land.
